content.description: A few feet right of Black Beard lock into a short crack to a horizontal and step right and up to a good ledge. Then up a slabby face to the anchors.
content.protection: Black Diamond C3's up to a C4 #.75 with bolted anchors at the top.
content.location: Paradise Main Wall Right just to the right of Black Beard.

content.description: Enjoy techy moves through the first bolt (easier if tall).  The crux (significantly easier if tall) is at the obvious blank section, where moving to the right is on the next route and will drop the grade.
content.protection: Mostly bolted, but you'll want to supplement with small-to-medium gear.  Fixed anchors at the top.
content.location: This climb is the leftmost bolted slab line, about 10 or 20 feet to the right of Roof of Madness.  The bolted line immediately to the right of this climb is Broken Finger (5.7).  Ground-up climbing only - the anchors are probably not accessible from above.

content.description: One of the best at Moc.  Climb straight through the bolt line passing two roofs.  The final roof is excellent and consists of a jug haul out to the final roof crack.
content.protection: Bolts, the rusty bolts up high can be easily supplemented with small to medium cams
content.location: Located on the right side of the I-beam amphitheater, to the right of Chicken Legs.  An obvious low roof with the first bolt marking the lip. Start behind a small pine tree.  Two bolt anchor with hangers only.

content.description: Start just to the right of Rambo under a bolt and a small ceiling. Fly to a horizontal under the ceiling and then move left to join the Rambo route.
content.location: Just to the right of Rambo under the small ceiling.

content.description: Follow a corner to bolt with a horizontal capped ceiling. Move up to another bolt then into a shallow corner, then to the top.
content.protection: Two bolts but a little run out between the second bolt and the anchor.
content.location: The Rambo wall at the shallow cave.

content.description: Climb small ledges to the crux mantle about 15' below the anchors.
content.protection: There are two bolts on this route plus the anchors.
content.location: This is the leftmost climb on the Hickory Wall.

content.description: Climb ledges to a small roof. Work your way over the roof to the anchors.
content.protection: Black Diamond C3's up to a C4 #1 and anchors over the roof.
content.location: Located on the Hickory wall around the arete to the right of Hickory.

climbs.name: New Generation - 5.12a
climbs.fa: John Peterson (FA)  Albert Pisaneschi, George Peterson, B. DÂ’ Antonio (FFA)

content.description: Double roof route. Original route was considered 5.12, may be a little easier now.
content.location: Far left end of the Main Area at Paradise.

content.description: Climb the center face of the Hickory wall. This route has some cracks and good ledges.
content.protection: Black Diamond C3's up to a C4 #.5 with bolted anchors at the top.
content.location: On the center face of the Hickory wall to the right of Pine.

content.description: Look for the mineral deposits and chalk running down the wall, step up the the incut in the rock below the bolt. follow the route straight up, first crux between the first two bolts. (Hint: finger lock) after that continue straight up to the the second crux below 3rd bolt. after that head up, pull through the over hand and head up and left to the bolted anchor. Enjoy
content.protection: Finger to hand sized cams, 4 Bolts, Bolted anchors at top.
content.location: Look for the white mineral deposits running down the face, starts at the incut in the rock blow the bolts.

content.description: Climb the arete on the Hickory Wall just to the right of Maple. There are a few good crimps and a nice ledge at the crux near the top of the route.
content.location: The arete on the Hickory wall just to the right of Maple.

content.description:
A surprisingly fun route on solid rock.  A bouldery move just off the deck is the business and a fall wouldn't be recommended until you get gear in the first horizontal crack.  The climbing is straight forward once you hit the horizontal but gear is a little sparce. 

  Undoubtedly someone else has lead this route before.  If anyone knows the FA then let me know.
content.protection: A couple cams, a red camalot and green alien worked for me
content.location: On the right side of the rambo wall, start at a corner where the overhanging rambo wall joins the slab.  Continue strait up to a small pine tree, trending right reduces the grade.

content.description: Mild overhang 30 ft up. Crack offers great protection.
content.protection: All pro with bolted anchors at start. Standard rack: nuts and duplicates of #1 and below cams.
content.location: Follow the obvious crack where the wall creates a 90 degree angle. Start over a little growth. 50' to 60' up, join 'New Generation' to hit the bolted anchor.

content.description: Crux seams to be right off the ground since you need to stabilize using the finger cracks as you smear on the adjacent slab. once you finish the slabcrack you need to get around a protruding feature and traverse up and right then out on to the face at the top of blackbeard ending at the anchors above.
content.protection: Standard rack, maybe some micro cams for the first 15 feet would help. Bolted anchors at top with rap chains.
content.location: Starts left of blackbeard at an obvious left leaning finger crack/ slab combination

content.description: Though the roof is a little intimidating, the crux is probably on the lower face.  Layback the roof flake to a welcome jug.  Missing the third clip would be a safe but "uncomfortable" fall.  After the roof, easy run-out climbing leads to a nice two bolt anchor.
content.location: Just left of New Generation.  Climbs past a two bolt face to the obvious roof with a large left facing flake.

content.description:
Power through a bulge approx 10 feet off the ground at the first bolt, then follow the bolt line straight to the last bolt of I-beam.  The top of the route is sustained and fun but the crux for me was definitely at the first bolt.     

  There are multiple ways to finish this route but I feel this is way makes the most sense.
content.location: The next bolted route to the right of I-beam.  Rejoins I-beam high on the wall.  Possible to rap off I-beams anchor.

content.description:
Holzman calls this one of the best 12s in PA and I wouldn't argue, especially if you like crimps.  The splashed orange color and rippling feet add to the enjoyment. 

  Angle up a left slanting rail to some small but reasonable holds to make the first clip.  A fall here wouldn't be fun without a boulder pad (stick-clipping is for pansies).  After the heinous clip blast through a thin section of micro-crimps and small feet.  Another powerful move awaits after the second clip (also tough).  Once established on the horizontal above the second bolt, take a deep breath and climb some easier ground to the anchors.
content.protection: two bolts, trad gear can be added but isn't necessary
content.location: Located at the first buttress after the opening amphitheater, look for brilliant orange lichen plastering the wall.  Climbing direct without out the left-leaning rail adds a number grade.  New anchors but no chains or rap rings.

content.description: Paradise is one of the first walls you will see on your way to the Library. The routes are trad leads, with a few supplemental bolts drilled where pro is scarce.
